0.rationale:
Current snake head at (6,8), staring toward apple at (7,6) — that’s one unit right and two units up (since (7,6) is x=7, y=6; from (6,8), down is negative y, so (7,6) is +1 in x, -2 in y relative). The closest apple is at (7,6), just one cell right and two cells up. Since the snake is at the head, moving RIGHT (7,8) would reach (7,8) and miss the apple by not going to (7,6). But (7,6) is directly two units above and one right. The snake can move UP (decrease y) but not enough. Alternatively, moving RIGHT and UP isn’t allowed — control is one direction only.  

The apple at (7,6) is viable and only accessible by moving right to x=7 and staying at y=6, but the snake can only move one step per turn. From (6,8), moving right to (7,8) is one move, but that’s not the apple. Moving up from (6,8) to (6,7) or (6,9) avoids the apple. The immediate best move is to move RIGHT to (7,8), as (7,6) is two units away diagonally, and a snake’s head can’t jump or move diagonally.  

However, both apples at (7,6) and the enemy snake at (6,0) are threats — but the snake’s next move must prioritize growing by capturing an apple. The only way to gain is to position under an apple. Since (7,6) is a valid target and required for growth, and it's only one right and two up, the minimal step right to x=7 brings the head closer. But to hit (7,6), the snake must move to (7,6), which is diagonal — not possible in one move.  

Given the rules, the snake must move a single direction. Moving RIGHT (x+1) brings head to (7,8); moving UP (y-) goes to (6,7), still not (7,6). The apple at (7,6) cannot be reached in one straight line. But since (7,6) is just
